column5: The former owner of Bow Narrows Lodge on Red Lake, Dan Baughman, is writing a series of articles on his families ownership of the lodge. If you have any history buff in you I think you might find it very interesting.https://aintlifewild.blogspot.com/
I have been reading it. I find it very interesting. Im looking forward yo the next instalment.
Great reading. Many of the resorts in Canada, and in the U.S., have interesting and entertaining histories. Glad to see someone recording the history of one.

Interesting to see how the camps and the business has evolved. Most of it has been driven by technology but customer expectations also change. About 10 years ago our group went to an outpost that had an indoor bathroom. After a week it was like wow! Not sure we could go back to an outhouse. At first it really restricted our options but now we see more and more outfitters putting in full bathrooms in at least at some of their outposts.
I enjoy learning about the history of Red Lake and surrounding area. Anyone know what some of the better Red Lake history books might be ??

If you enjoy history of the the North also check out North to Cree Lake. A wonderful account of the Karras brothers during our first depression trapping in Northern Saskatchewan and Cree Lake. My brothers and I have fished Cree Lake several times and actually scouted the remains of one of their cabins. These guys led a tough life.

I have followed Dan's blog since 2014 when he owned Bow Narrows Camp and now as well. Although I have never stayed at Bow Narrows, it is on my to do list of fishing spots just because of his writing and history lessons of the area over the years. PjShorthorn
